unit: Unit 7 | Inference for Quantitative Data: Means
title: Males/Females ACT
question_text:
Suppose a two-sample T-test hypothesizes that $H_0: { u }_{ 1 }= { u }_{ 2 }$ vs. $H_a: { u }_{ 1 } > { u }_{ 2 }$
Let ${ u }_{ 1 }$= the ACT score of all males in the U.S. Let ${ u }_{ 2 }$= the ACT score of all females in the U.S.
The two-sample $T$-test gives a $p$-value of $0.013$.
When testing at the $5\%$ level, one can conclude that

choices.text: There is no evidence to suggest males score higher than females on the ACT.
There is no evidence to suggest males and females score the same as each other.
Significant evidence exists to accept the alternative hypothesis.
Significant evidence exists to reject the null hypothesis.
No evidence exists to claim males and females score the same.

solution:
When performing a hypothesis test, all conclusions must be in the context of the null hypothesis. A low $p$-value, relative to alpha, will give evidence to reject the null hypothesis. A high $p$-value relative to alpha will fail to give evidence to reject the null.

In this situation, since the $p$-value of $1.3\%$ is less than $5\%$, there is sufficient evidence to reject the null hypothesis.

Thus, the correct answer is Choice 'D'.
